facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 8N of 1971 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 8  N  of 1971. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated July 18, 1969 of Calcutta High Court, Original Decree No. 115 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 18, 1969 of the Calcutta High Court from Original Decree No. 115 of 1968.

facts.text: Matrimonial suit No. 17 of 1966 filed by appellant against respondent for declaration of marriage null and void and custody of children.

anchor.surface_text: ment of the Calcutta High Court arising out of a matrimonial suit No. 17 of 1966 filed by the appellant against the respondent for a decree declaring that the marriage between the parties was null and void and asking for custody and care of the children. alimony pendente life permanent maintenance and other reliefs.

facts.text: Action filed in July 1966 on original side of High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear that the appellant left the home of the respondent in the year 1965 and the action out of which the appeal has arisen was filed in July 1966 on the original side of the High Court.

facts.text: Suit dismissed by Mr. Justice Ghose.

anchor.surface_text: It was dismissed by Mr. Justice Ghose and the appeal under the Letters Patent was also dismissed by the Division Bench.

facts.text: Letters Patent appeal dismissed by Division Bench.

anchor.surface_text: It was dismissed by Mr. Justice Ghose and the appeal under the Letters Patent was also dismissed by the Division Bench.

facts.text: Appellant and respondent are close relations, their mothers being real sisters.

anchor.surface_text: The facts may first be stated. The appellant and the res- pondent are close relations their mothers being real sisters.

facts.text: Prior to January 30, 1960, appellant and respondent had sexual relations, appellant became pregnant.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that prior to January 30, 1960 they had sexual relations as a result of which the appellant became enciente  pregnant .

facts.text: Respondent originally Hindu, converted to Christianity and professed Roman Catholic faith.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent who was originally a Hindu had got companyverted to Christianity and professed the Roman Catholic faith.

facts.text: Appellant Hindu, converted to Christianity, baptised on January 29, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who was also a Hindu got companyverted to that faith and was baptised on January 29, 1960.

facts.text: Marriage solemnised on January 30, 1960 by Father Antoine at Church of St. Ignatius, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: On January 30, 1960 one Father Antoine solemnised the marriage of the parties at the Church of St. Ignatius, Calcutta.

facts.text: First child, a daughter, born to appellant on May 10, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On May 10, 1960 the first child, a daughter, was born to the appellant.

facts.text: Second child, a daughter, born in October 1961.

anchor.surface_text: She gave birth to a second child, also a daughter, in October 1961.

facts.text: Appellant left respondent's home in 1965.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear that the appellant left the home of the respondent in the year 1965

facts.text: Petitioner alleged sexual relations started under duress, intimidation, undue influence, resulting in pregnancy.

anchor.surface_text: In the petition a number of allegations were made relating to the companyduct of the respondent. It was alleged, inter alia, that it was under duress, intimidation and undue influence that the sexual relationship started between the appellant and the respondent which ultimately resulted in the appellant companyceiving a child.

facts.text: Petitioner alleged conversion to Christianity and marriage due to fraud, coercion, undue influence by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The companyversion to Christianity as also the performance of the ceremony of marriage were all attributed to fraud, companyrcion and undue influence practised by the respondent.

facts.text: Petitioner claimed she was minor at time of marriage, no consent of father or guardian, no free consent.

anchor.surface_text: It was claimed that the appellant was a minor at the time the marriage was solemnised and the companysent of her father or her guardian was number taken number did she give her own companysent freely to the marriage.

facts.text: Petitioner claimed marriage void due to prohibited degree of consanguinity.

anchor.surface_text: Further the marriage was void because the parties were within the prohibited degree of companysanguinity.

facts.text: All allegations denied by respondent, gave his version of relationship development and marriage.

anchor.surface_text: All these allegations were denied by the respondent. He gave his own version as to how the intimate relationship between the parties came to be developed and how the marriage was ultimately solemnised.

facts.text: Trial judge found parties fell in love leading to marriage, rejected fraud/coercion claims.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial judge came to the companyclusion that the appellant and the respondent fell in love with each other which led to their marriage. He did number accept the case of the appellant  hat any fraud, companyrcion or undue influence had been practised or employed by the respondent

facts.text: Trial judge held marriage solemnised by proper priest after dispensation for consanguinity.

anchor.surface_text: It was further held that the, marriage had been solemnised by the proper priest after a dispensation had been obtained from the authorities of the Roman Catholic Church removing the impediment of companysanguinity.

facts.text: Division Bench endorsed trial judge's view on circumstances of marriage.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench endorsed the view of the trial judge about the circumstances in which the marriage came to be solemnised between the parties.

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.19 Indian Christian Marriage Act not applicable as marriage by category 1 s.5 person.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the High Court was right in holding that the provisions of s. 19 of the Christian Marriage Act will number be applicable to the present case since it was solemnized by a person falling under s. 5 1

facts.text: Supreme Court held marriage valid under Canon Law despite minority, no parental consent required if above puberty age.

anchor.surface_text: under Canon Law so long as a minor has reached the age of capacity to companytract which, as stated before, is 16 years in case of a man and 14 years in case of a girl the marriage can be solemnized and the lack or absence of companysent of the parents or guardian will number invalidate the marriage.

facts.text: Parties within second degree consanguinity, impediment removed by dispensation.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the companysanguinity between the parties to the marriage in the present case is of the second degree and Therefore it was an impediment in the way of the marriage under the Canon law.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.19 applies only to Part III marriages by licensed Ministers (s.5 category 3), not episcopally ordained ministers (s.5(1)); confirmed by scheme of Act and precedent

arguments.claim: s.19 Indian Christian Marriage Act is of general application to any Minister solemnizing Christian marriage, based on section wording and heading not limiting

anchor.surface_text: It has been necessary to set out in some detail the provisions of the Indian Christian Marriage Act because it has been strenuously argued on behalf of the appellant that since the companysent of her father was number taken under s. 19 when she was admittedly a minor the marriage was null and void. It has been pointed out that even though the heading of Part III in which s. 19 occurs confines the provisions therein to marriages solemnized by the Minister of Religion licensed under the Act, s. 19 is of general application and whenever a Christian marriage is solemnized by any priest or Minister its provisions would be applicable.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: III only applies to Ministers of Religion licensed under the Act. Section 19 companyld number, therefore, be applicable to the marriage of the appell

arguments.court_reasoning: Scheme of s.5 categorizes solemnizers; Parts III, V, VI apply specifically to categories 3,4,5; category 1 exempt

arguments.claim: Provisions of Indian Christian Marriage Act Parts III, V, VI apply only to specific categories of solemnizers under s.5(3),(4),(5), not to episcopally ordained under s.5(1)

anchor.surface_text: We may now deal with the scheme of s. 5 which read with s. 4 is the most material section and all the other provisions which have been made in the Act, particularly, in the different Parts have to be read in the light of s. 5. Section 5 gives five categories of persons by whom marriages of Christians can be solemnized in India.

arguments.claim: Part III s.19 applies only to Ministers licensed under the Act (following Rev. Father Caussavel v. Rev. Saurez)

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that after a careful analysis of the scheme of the Indian Christian Marriage Act it was held in Rev. Father Caussavel v. Rev. Saurez that Part III only applies to Ministers of Religion licensed under the Act.

holdings.text: The provisions of s. 19 of the Indian Christian Marriage Act will not be applicable to the present case since it was solemnized by a person falling under s. 5(1)

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the High Court was right in holding that the provisions of s. 19 of the Christian Marriage Act will number be applicable to the present case since it was solemnized by a person falling under s. 5 1

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of s.5 categorizes solemnizers into 5 groups; Parts III, V, VI apply only to categories 3,4,5; category 1 (episcopal ordination) exempt; follows Rev. Father Caussavel precedent

holdings.text: The marriage could not be held to be null and void on the ground that since the appellant was below 21 years of age the consent of her father was not obtained

anchor.surface_text: For all the reasons mentioned before we are in entire agreement with the view expressed by the High Court that the marriage of the appellant with the respondent companyld number be held to be null and void on the ground that since the appellant was below 21 years of age the companysent of her father was number obtained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.19 ICMA inapplicable; additionally, under Canon Law (Canons 88,1067), minor above 14 (girl) can validly marry without parental consent

holdings.text: For the purpose of deciding the validity of the marriage, would be the law of the Roman Catholic Church, namely, the Canon law of that Church

anchor.surface_text: That, for the purpose of deciding the validity of the marriage, would be the law of the Roman Catholic Church,namely, the Canon law of that Church.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.19 Divorce Act does not define prohibited degrees; personal law (Canon Law) governs capacity and impediments for Roman Catholics; follows s.88 ICMA, Peter Philip Saldanha

holdings.text: After dispensation has been granted by the competent authority of the Roman Catholic Church the parties who are within the prohibited degree of consanguinity can still be regarded as within those degrees

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether after dispensation has been granted by the companypetent authority of the Roman Catholic Church the parties who are within the prohibited degree of companysanguinity can still be regarded as within those degrees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dispensation (Canons 1040,1052,80-86) relaxes impediment of second degree consanguinity; parties no longer within prohibited degree post-dispensation; presumption of validity if by competent priest

holdings.text: Once dispensation is granted by the appropriate authorities the parties cannot be regarded under the Canon law as being within the prohibited degrees with the result that ground No. 2 in s. 19 cannot be availed of

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment once dispensation is granted by the appropriate authorities the parties cannot be regarded under the Canon law as being within the prohibited degrees with the result that ground No. 2 in s. 19 cannot be availed of.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prohibited degrees per Canon Law; dispensation removes impediment; follows V.H. Lopez, H.A. Lucas precedents; strong presumption of validity

precedents.citation: Rev. Father Caussavel v. Rev. Saurez 1

anchor.surface_text: it was held in Rev. Father Caussavel v. Rev. Saurez 1  that Part III only applies to Ministers of Religion licensed under the Act. Section 19 companyld number, therefore, be applicable to the marriage of the appellant and the respondent which was solemnized by a person in category 1 of s. 5. Moreover as demonstrated by s. 60 there seems to be numberuniform provision that companysent must be obtained of the parents or the guardian when a person is above 18 years of age but below 21.

precedents.cited_proposition: Part III only applies to Ministers of Religion licensed under the Act
precedents.cited_holding: Part III only applies to Ministers of Religion licensed under the Act

precedents.citation: V. H. Lopez v. R. J. Lopez 1

anchor.surface_text: The High Court followed the decision of a full bench of the Calcutta High Court in V. H. Lopez v. R. J. Lopez 1  in which it was held that the prohibited degrees for the purpose of the marriage were those which were prohibited by the customary law of the Church to which the parties belonged. in that case also the parties were Roman Catholic and the ceremony of marriage was solemnized by the I.L R.12 Cal. 706.

precedents.case_name: V. H. Lopez v. R. J. Lopez
precedents.cited_proposition: prohibited degrees for the purpose of the marriage were those which were prohibited by the customary law of the Church to which the parties belonged

precedents.citation: H. A. Lucas v. Theodoras Lucas 1

anchor.surface_text: According to the decision in H. A. Lucas v. Theodoras Lucas 1  the companyrts in India win number disallow a Roman Catholic of Indian domicile who had received the necessary dispensation from marrying his deceased wifes sister who by the law of her own Church, which was Armenian in that case, may be incapable of companytracting the marriage. The husbands capacity rendered the marriage valid in law.

precedents.case_name: H. A. Lucas v. Theodoras Lucas
precedents.cited_proposition: courts in India will not disallow a Roman Catholic of Indian domicile who had received the necessary dispensation from marrying within prohibited degrees; husband's capacity renders marriage valid

precedents.citation: Peter Philip Saldanha v. Anne Grace Saldanha 2

anchor.surface_text: The effect of s. 88 of the Indian Christian Marriage Act was companysidered in Peter Philip Saldanha v. Anne Grace Saldanha 2 . That section provides that numberhing in the Act shall be deemed to validate any marriage which the personal law applicable to either of the parties forbids him or her to enter into. In the Bombay case the parties were Roman Catholic of Goan domicile and their marriage had been solemnized before the Registrar of Marriages in Bombay.

precedents.case_name: Peter Philip Saldanha v. Anne Grace Saldanha
precedents.cited_proposition: expression 'personal law' in s. 88 refers to capacity to contract and impediments, not forms of solemnization
precedents.cited_holding: the expression personal law in s. 88 refers to the capacity to companytract and impediments and number the forms of solemnization

precedents.citation: V. H. Lopez v. E. J. Lopez 1

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of fact in V. H. Lopez v. E. J. Lopez 1  it was laid down as long ago as the year 1885 A.D. that the prohibited degrees mentioned in s. 19 of the Indian Divorce Act did number necessarily mean the degrees prohibited by the Law of England. For finding out prohibited degrees it was the customary law of the class to which the parties belonged.

precedents.case_name: V. H. Lopez v. E. J. Lopez
precedents.cited_proposition: prohibited degrees mentioned in s. 19 of the Indian Divorce Act did not necessarily mean the degrees prohibited by the Law of England; customary law of the class to which parties belonged applies; strong presumption of validity if solemnized by competent clergyman

precedents.citation: H. A. Lucas v. Theodore Lucas 1

anchor.surface_text: In the subsequent decision H. A. Lucas v. Theodore Lucas 1  the earlier decision in Lopez v. Lopez 1  was referred to and followed.

precedents.case_name: H. A. Lucas v. Theodore Lucas
precedents.cited_proposition: referred to and followed the earlier Lopez decision

anchor.surface_text: In the subsequent decision H. A. Lucas v. Theodore Lucas 1  the earlier decision in Lopez v. Lopez 1  was referred to and followed. Our attention has number been drawn by the learned companynsel for the appellant to any companytrary decision and we companysider that the law was companyrectly enunciated in Lopez v. Lopez 1

and we companysider that the law was companyrectly enunciated in Lonez v. Lopez 1  on the effect of dispensation which held the field for all these years on the question that once dispensation has been obtained from the appropriate authorities of the Roman Catholic Church a marriage between the parties who are within the prohibited degrees of companysanguinity is number null and void

precedents.cited_proposition: law correctly enunciated on effect of dispensation; once obtained, marriage not null and void

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; no decree declaring the marriage null and void granted to the appellant.
